title: 106_s2390
content: The Act titled "Project Exile: The Safe Streets and Neighborhoods Act of 2000" establishes a program for Firearms Sentencing Incentive Grants under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. This includes definitions related to the grants. The Act "Project Exile: The Safe Streets and Neighborhoods Act of 2000" defines key terms related to firearms, violent crimes, and serious drug trafficking crimes. The Act "Project Exile: The Safe Streets and Neighborhoods Act of 2000" defines key terms related to firearms, violent crimes, and serious drug trafficking crimes. It includes definitions for "unit of local government" and "violent crime," specifying the types of crimes considered under the latter term. The Act "Project Exile: The Safe Streets and Neighborhoods Act of 2000" defines key terms related to firearms, violent crimes, and serious drug trafficking crimes, including definitions for "unit of local government" and "violent crime." SEC. 20352 authorizes grants. The Attorney General awards Firearms Sentencing Incentive Grants to eligible States for specific uses, including supporting law enforcement agencies, courts, and criminal history records. Grants can also be used for public awareness programs and community support. The Attorney General awards grants to States for various purposes, including supporting law enforcement agencies, courts, and criminal history records. States can use grants to build or expand correctional facilities and may also make subgrants to local government units within the State. "SEC. 20353. FIREARMS SENTENCING INCENTIVE GRANTS." To be eligible for a grant award under this section, a State must submit an application to the Attorney General showing implementation of firearms sentencing laws requiring a minimum 5-year imprisonment for using a firearm in a violent or serious drug trafficking crime. Any person with a prior conviction for a violent crime who possesses a firearm will be sentenced to a minimum of 5 years in prison. States must implement a public awareness program to support firearms sentencing laws and coordinate with the federal government for crime reduction in high-crime areas. The application for grants in high-crime areas must coordinate with Federal prosecutors and law enforcement agencies to promote Federal involvement in law enforcement. States must allocate resources to reduce crime in these areas. States unable to meet eligibility requirements can still receive grants by providing assurances in their application. The State must have an equivalent Federal prosecution agreement in place to ensure prosecution under Federal law for certain specified conduct. If a person's conviction under State law for certain conduct is not guaranteed to result in a specified sentence, they may be prosecuted for that conduct under Federal law. The amount available for grants under this subtitle for any fiscal year is allocated to each eligible State based on the number of part 1 violent crimes reported. If data is unavailable or inaccurate, the Attorney General will use the best comparable data for the previous year for fund allocation. "Authorization of appropriations for grants under this subtitle is allocated to each eligible State based on reported part 1 violent crimes. Attorney General will use best comparable data if current data is unavailable." Authorization of appropriations for grants under this subtitle is allocated to each eligible State based on reported part 1 violent crimes, with specific funding amounts authorized for fiscal years 2001 to 2005. Funds must be used for designated purposes and cannot supplant State funds, with a limit of 3 percent for administrative costs. The Attorney General can use up to 3 percent of funds for administrative costs, research, and data collection. Appropriated funds remain available until expended, and the Federal share of a grant cannot exceed 90 percent of the proposal costs. The Attorney General is required to submit a report to Congress on the implementation of a specific subtitle, including details on state eligibility and fund distribution. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of contents regarding firearms sentencing incentive grants. Subtitle D--Firearms Sentencing Incentive Grants includes definitions, authorization of grants, formula for grants, and authorization of appropriations for firearms sentencing incentive grants. The Attorney General is also required to submit a report on the implementation of this subtitle.
